he: והקיפה: מאי קיפה אמר רבה פירמא
text: §The mishna teaches: The spices [kifa] join together with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food, but an egg-bulk of kifa itself is not susceptible to impurity. The Gemara asks: To what is the term kifa referring? Rabba said: The term kifa is referring to a congealed hash of cooked meat that settled to the bottom of the pot.

he:
286 / (שבת עד:) / פרים
מינציי"ר / mincier / לקצוץ, לרסק
✭ to mince
heVersionTitleInHebrew: אוצר לעזי רש"י, תל אביב, תשמ"ח
sourceHeRef: אוצר לעזי רש"י, תלמוד, שבת קצ״א

he: וְהַטּוֹחֵן. אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הַאי מַאן דְּפָרֵים סִילְקָא — חַיָּיב מִשּׁוּם טוֹחֵן. אָמַר רַב מְנַשֶּׁה: הַאי מַאן דְּסָלֵית סִילְתֵּי — חַיָּיב מִשּׁוּם טוֹחֵן. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: אִי קָפֵיד אַמִּשְׁחֲתָא — חַיָּיב מִשּׁוּם מְחַתֵּךְ.
text: We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: And one who grinds. Rav Pappa said: One who chops beets into small pieces on Shabbat is liable due to the prohibited labor of grinding, as the actions are similar. Rav Menashe said: One who chops wood chips for sawdust (Rambam) is liable due to the prohibited labor of grinding. Rav Ashi said: If he is particular in his chopping with regard to the measurement, i.e., he is careful to cut all the chips to a particular size, he is also liable due to the labor of cutting.
